choices.A: To ensure that the change control approach is appropriate for the size of the project
choices.D: To ensure that the project remains viable against its approved business case
choices.C: To ensure that responsibilities are defined for directing, managing and delivering the project
choices.B: To ensure that themes can be applied using techniques that are appropriate to the project

discussion.content:
D is correct; The other options are not the primary purpose of this theme:

A. To ensure that the change control approach is appropriate for the size of the project: This is related to the "change" theme.
B. To ensure that themes can be applied using techniques that are appropriate to the project: This is related to the "tailor to suit the project" principle.
C. To ensure that responsibilities are defined for directing, managing and delivering the project: This is related to the "organization" theme.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct. Progress is the measure of the achievement of the objectives of a plan. Controlling progress is central to project management, ensuring that the project remains viable against its approved business case.

Which are PRINCE2 principles?
1. Continued business justification
2. Managing product delivery
3. Controlling a stage
4. Learn from experience

discussion.content:
Here are the 7 PRINCE2 principles:

1. Continued Business Justification
2. Learn from Experience
3. Defined Roles and Responsibilities   
4. Manage by Stages   
5. Manage by Exception   
6. Focus on Products   
7. Tailor to Suit the Project Environment

questions.question_text:
Which are purposes of a highlight report?
1. To escalate a tolerance deviation to the project board
2. To provide a summary of stage status to the project board
3. To allow the project board to monitor project progress
4. To update the project manager on the progress of a work package

discussion.content:
Why the others are not correct:
Purpose 1: While the highlight report can mention issues or risks, escalating a tolerance deviation (such as a budget or schedule overrun) is typically handled through formal exception reports, not highlight reports. Highlight reports are meant to summarize progress, not specifically escalate deviations.

Purpose 4: The highlight report is directed to the Project Board, not the Project Manager. The Project Manager would generally receive more detailed information through other means, such as work package reports or direct communication from team managers.

D is correct; The other options are not time-driven controls:

A. End stage report: This is an event-driven control, produced at the end of a stage.
B. Project brief: This is the initial document that triggers the project, not a control mechanism.
C. Project initiation documentation: This is a collection of documents produced during the "starting up a project" process and is not a time-driven control

Which is an advantage of applying the 'continued business justification' principle?

choices.B: Duplication of project objectives is less likely across an organization's portfolio
choices.C: All projects have a business justification documented in a formal business case
choices.D: Regular revalidation ensure that all funds allocated to the project will be used
choices.A: Legislative projects do not require a business justification before initiation

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
i think the key word is an advantage... B is correct

Selected Answer: C
The correct answer is:
C. All projects have a business justification documented in a formal business case

Explanation:
The 'Continued Business Justification' principle ensures that every project has a valid reason to proceed, which is captured in a formal business case. This justification is reviewed and revalidated at key stages throughout the project lifecycle, ensuring that the project remains aligned with business objectives and continues to deliver value.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct because applying the "continued business justification" principle prevents duplication of project objectives within an organisation's portfolio, ensuring that all projects contribute uniquely to business goals.

Selected Answer: B
Poor alignment with corporate, programme management or customer strategies can also result in organizations having a portfolio of projects that have mutually inconsistent or duplicated objectives.

Selected Answer: D
D. Regular revalidation ensures that all funds allocated to the project will be used.

The continued business justification principle ensures that a project remains aligned with its business goals and that it continues to be justified throughout its life cycle. Regular revalidation of the business case helps confirm that the project remains worthwhile, and it ensures that resources (such as funds) are being used effectively and appropriately.

B is correct, please change;
While the other options have some relevance, they are not the most direct advantages:

A. Legislative projects do not require a business justification before initiation: While some legislative projects might have a different type of justification, the principle of continued justification still applies to ensure they remain relevant and necessary.
C. All projects have a business justification documented in a formal business case: While a business case is a common way to document justification, other methods might be used, and the focus is on the ongoing assessment, not just the initial documentation.   
D. Regular revalidation ensures that all funds allocated to the project will be used: While revalidation can help with budget control, the primary focus is on ensuring the project's continued value and alignment with strategic goals.
I would have said B also.

I think B is correct. 3.1 ...Organizations that lack rigour in business justification may find that projects proceed even when there are few real benefits or when a project has only tentative associations with the corporate, programme management or customer strategies. Poor alignment with corporate, programme management or customer strategies can also result in organizations having a portfolio of projects that have mutually inconsistent or duplicated objectives.
